courses.subject: Elective
courses.enrollmentNotes: n/a
courses.courseDescription: Leadworthy is a highly engaging class that helps students grow as leaders in their schools and communities. The course emphasizes individual responsibility through time -management and organization while also encouraging creativity, critical thinking, and c ollaboration. These opportunities build student confidence, strengthen leadership skills, and support personal growth. Students may be required to purchase a shirt. NOTE: This course satisfies the FHSPE communications skills component for students entering the 10th, 11th, and 12th grades during the 25- 26 school year. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Elective
courses.enrollmentNotes: Current member of Texas Academic Decathlon (TAD) or instructor approval.
courses.courseDescription: In Academic Decathlon students experience the challenges of rigorous competition through team participation in ten academic events: Art, Economics, Essay Writing, Interview, Language and Literature, Mathematics, Music, Science, Social Science, and Speech. Each year, these subjects are integrated around a central curricular theme, providing a broad academic challenge. Students will learn and demonstrate effective written and oral communication. collaboration. problem-solving and critical and creative thinking skills. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: English Language Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: Students must complete the full credit for this course to satisfy the communication skills
courses.courseDescription: AP Seminar is an interdisciplinary course that uses an inquiry approach to engage students in conversations that explore the complexities of academic and real -world topics and issues by analyzing varying perspectives. Students will consider issues through a variety of lenses and from multiple perspectives, many of which are divergent or competing. Students will participate in collaborative and independent performance tasks and an end-of-course exam to earn AP credit. AP Seminar is the first required course for the AP Capstone Diploma program. Students must complete the full credit in order for this course to satisfy the communication skills component and to continue to AP Research. Available only at campuses which applied to and were approved by College Board to offer this course. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: English Language Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: n/a
courses.courseDescription: AP Research, the second course in the AP Capstone experience, allows students to deeply explore an academic topic, problem, issue, or idea of individual interest. Students design, plan, and implement a yearlong investigation to address a research question. Through this inquiry, students further the skills they acquired in the AP Seminar course by learning research methodology, employing ethical research practices, and accessing, analyzing, and synthesizing information. Students reflect on their skill development, document their processes, and curate the artifacts of their scholarly work through a process and reflection portfolio. The course culminates in an academic paper of 4,000 - 5,000 words (accompanied by a performance, exhibit, or product where applicable) and a presentation with an oral defense. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Elective
courses.enrollmentNotes: Students must complete an application and be accepted into the PAL program before registering for this
courses.courseDescription: This course develops student leaders who serve as trained peer mentors and role models. PALs work with students on their own campus as well as in feeder middle and elementary schools, building connections that foster confidence, resilien ce, and a sense of belonging. Through their influence, PALs create a more positive school culture while gaining valuable skills in communication, leadership, and problem -solving ‚Äîexperience that benefits them now and in future careers such as teaching, counseling , and other helping professions. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.enrollmentNotes: Students must complete an application and be accepted into the PAL program before registering for this
courses.courseDescription: The PAL class develops student leaders who mentor PAL 1 students, support peers on their campus, and assist learners in feeder schools. PALs build confidence, resilience, and a sense of belonging in others while gaining real -world skills in leadership, com munication, and problem -solving‚Äîpreparing them for future careers in helping professions. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: English Language Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: n/a
courses.courseDescription: Students explore the interconnected nature of language and literacy using grade appropriate texts across multiple genres for study and composition. Instructional emphasis is placed on developing the ability to respond to texts with origina l thoughts and co mmentary supported by text evidence. Students learn to identify and then apply the skills authors use when employing various literary devices and rhetorical strategies in their writing.

courses.subject: English Language Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: Requires campus approval prior to enrollment. Students must be enrolled in the Virtual Study Hall (0020VIR).
courses.courseDescription: Students explore the interconnected nature of reading, writing, speaking, listening and critical thinking using multiple genres for study and composition. Students develop research skills necessary to organize and present ideas and information while continuing to develop knowledge and skills with increased complexity and nuance in order to think critically and adapt to the ever-evolving nature of language and literacy.

courses.subject: English Language Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: n/a
courses.courseDescription: Students build on English I skills with more complex texts, continuing to make inferences and drawing more sophisticated conclusions that require more nuanced analysis of how literary devices contribute to meaning. Students are expected to compare and cont rast genres as they study a variety of world literature while continuing to develop composition, research and speaking skills.

courses.subject: English Language Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: n/a
courses.courseDescription: Students continue to build on previous knowledge as they become more independent learners and critical thinkers. American literature anchors the English III experience as the course analyzes the historical context of specific literary movements and explore s the effects of these authors‚Äô unique styles and their influence on the time period. During English III students embark on an exploration of a complex research question along with multiple writing opportunities including extended study in rhetorical analysis.

courses.subject: English Language Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: This course satisfies the 4th English credit requirements when taken along with successful completion of English 1, English 2, and English 3.
courses.courseDescription: English IV emphasizes reading a wide range of largely British texts and analyzing genre as a tool to communicate complex, universal ideas. Students will analyze how authors use literary devices and rhetorical techniques to achieve a specific purpose in a s ophisticated academic or persuasive text. Students will create polished, professional, and academic writings and presentations as they prepare for the transition from high school to college or career. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: English Language Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: n/a
courses.courseDescription: Advanced Placement English Language and Composition examines major elements of non-fiction and American literature. Additionally, students prepare for the AP English Language and Composition exam, with an emphasis on writing under time constraints. Students read from a variety of genres that address varying historical periods, disciplines, and rhetorical contexts. Students apply stylistic and rhetorical strategies and techniques to their own writings while reading and analyzing 5 -8 required anchor texts. Students enrolled in an Advanced Placement course are expected to take the corresponding AP exam. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.enrollmentNotes: This course satisfies the 4th English credit requirements when taken along with successful completion of English 1, English 2, and English 3. Students enrolled in an Advanced Placement course are expected to take the corresponding AP exam.
courses.courseDescription: Advanced Placement English Literature and Composition includes the study of prose and poetry by British and world authors from the 16th century through contemporary times. Students prepare for the AP English Literature and Composition exam by emphasizing writing under time constraints while also reading and analyzing 5- 8 required anchor texts during the school year. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.courseDescription: The English I KAP course prepares students for entry to the Advanced Placement English courses. Students develop critical reading skills by analyzing a variety of literary and informational texts from different cultures and time periods. Additionally, writ ing skills are strengthened by constructing clear, evidence -based literary arguments with a strong command of grammar and style. The course will highlight reading closely, selecting text evidence, and noticing language choices.

courses.subject: English Language Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: n/a
courses.courseDescription: The English II KAP course prepares students for entry to the Advanced Placement English courses. The course will focus on analyzing how writers use rhetorical choices to create meaning in both literary and nonfiction texts. The course moves beyond basic co mprehension to evaluate the author's purpose, structure, and language ‚Äîhoning students‚Äô ability to craft and support a nuanced argument. Through close reading and analytical writing, students will explore diverse genres and voices, preparing them for the challenges of AP English as well as the critical thinking required in college and professional life.

courses.subject: English Language Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: HCC admission requirement; TSI requirement; ENGL 1301
courses.courseDescription: English 4 ‚Äì Dual Credit 2322/2323 is a survey of the development of British literature from the Anglo - Saxon period to the Eighteenth Century. Students will study works of prose, poetry, drama, and fiction in relation to their historical, linguistic, and cultural contexts. Texts will be selected from a diverse group of authors and traditions. Students earn three college credit hours per semester upon successful completion of this course in addition to satisfying the high school English 4 graduation requirement. College credit is provided by Houston Community College (HCC). Successful completion of ENGL 1301 is required for enrollment.

courses.subject: English Language Arts

courses.subject: Math
courses.enrollmentNotes: n/a
courses.courseDescription: In this course, students will study linear, quadratic, and exponential functions and make connections between the functions, their related transformations, equations and their solutions in both mathematical and real- world situations. Calculators are available to students for in-class use when appropriate based on instruction. Katy ISD high school campuses currently use the TI-Nspire CX II calculator or Desmos, a free online graphing calculator. Students may access Desmos on any device with internet. If purchasing their own calculator, students should select one that offers the capabilities and features of the TI -Nspire CX II. Note: Beginning with the class of 2029, the grade for Algebra 1 will not count towards a student‚Äôs grade point average (GPA) if the student successfully completes 4 math credits in addition to successfully completing Algebra 1.

courses.subject: Math
courses.enrollmentNotes: Students who take AP Precalculus are not eligible to take Precalculus as the TEKS in Precalculus are duplicate in AP Precalculus.
courses.courseDescription: This course emphasizes a conceptual understanding of functions and their graphs and covers polynomial and rational functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, trigonometric and polar functions, and general functions involving parameters, vectors, and matrices. Students enrolled in an Advanced Placement course are expected to take the corresponding AP exam. Calculators are available to students for in-class use when appropriate based on instruction. Katy ISD Advanced Placement math courses currently use the TI-Nspire CX II calculator or Desmos, a free online graphing calculator. If purchasing their own calculator, students should select one that offers the capabilities and features of the TI-Nspire CX II and is on the approved College Board calculator list.

courses.subject: Math
courses.enrollmentNotes: This course is a third math credit option for FHSPE students. Students who have earned another third math credit course can take Math Models with Applications for elective credit only.
courses.courseDescription: Math Models with Applications, or MMA, provides a path for students to succeed in successive math courses and prepares them for various post-secondary choices. Real-life applications involve personal finance, science, engineering, fine arts and social sciences. Calculators are available to students for in-class use when appropriate based on instruction. Katy ISD high school campuses currently use the TI-Nspire CX II calculator or Desmos, a free online graphing calculator. Students may access Desmos on any device with internet. If purchasing their own calculator, students should select one that offers the capabilities and features of the TI-Nspire CX II. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Math
courses.enrollmentNotes: Multivariable Calculus is offered as a virtual course for students who have successfully completed AP Calculus BC. There is no academic equivalent for this course.
courses.courseDescription: In this course, students take the concepts learned in the single variable calculus course and extend them to multiple dimensions. Topics covered include vectors, vector valued functions, coordinate systems, surfaces, partial derivatives, multiple integrals and vector calculus. These mathematical tools and methods are used extensively in the physical sciences, engineering, economics and computer graphics. Calculators are available to students for in -class use when appropriate based on instruction. Katy ISD high school campuses currently use the TI-Nspire CX II calculator or Desmos, a free online graphing calculator. Students may access Desmos on any device with the internet. If purchasing their own calculator, students should select one that offers the capabilities and features of the TI-Nspire CX II. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: Geometry KAP or Algebra 2 may be taken concurrently with this course.
courses.courseDescription: AP Computer Science A emphasizes programming methodology, procedural abstraction, in- depth study of algorithms, data structures and data abstractions and is taught in Java. Students enrolled in an AP course are expected to take the corresponding Advanced Placement exam. NOTE: Successful completion of this course awards one advanced math credit and one language other than English credit. The advanced math credit will be awarded with the student‚Äôs earned, numeric grade and corresponding grade points are calculated in the GPA. The Language Other than English credit will be awarded with the student‚Äôs earned, numeric grade but no grade points are calculated in the GPA. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.courseDescription: AP Computer Science A emphasizes programming methodology, procedural abstraction, in- depth study of algorithms, data structures and data abstractions and is taught in Java. Students enrolled in an AP course are expected to take the corresponding Advanced Placement exam. NOTE: Successful completion of this course awards one advanced math credit and one language other than English credit. The advanced math credit will be awarded with the student‚Äôs earned, numeric grade and corresponding grade points are calculated in the GPA. The Language Other than English credit will be awarded with the student‚Äôs earned, numeric grade but no grade points are calculated in the GPA. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Math
courses.enrollmentNotes: Students who take AP Calculus AB are not eligible to take the first semester of AP Calculus BC or AP Calculus BC/GT as the course content is the same. There is no academic equivalent for this course.
courses.courseDescription: AP Calculus AB is equivalent to the first semester of college -level Calculus. This course emphasizes a conceptual understanding of calculus utilizing a multi -representational approach and covers limits, derivatives, integrals, and approximation. Students enrolled in an Advanced Placement course are expected to take the corresponding AP exam. Calculators are available to students for in -class use when appropriate based on instruction. Katy ISD Advanced Placement math courses currently use the TI -Nspire CX II calculator or Desmos, a free online graphing calculator. If purchasing their own calculator, students should select one that offers the capabilities and features of the TI -Nspire CX II and is on the approved College Board calculator list.

courses.subject: Math
courses.enrollmentNotes: Students who take AP Calculus AB are not eligible to take the first semester of AP Calculus BC or AP Calculus BC/GT as the course content is the same. There is no academic equivalent for this course.
courses.courseDescription: AP Calculus BC is equivalent to two semesters of college -level Calculus and covers all course content of AP Calculus AB. Additional topics include parametric, polar and vector functions as well as polynomial, approximations and series. Students enrolled in an Advanced Placement course are expected to take the corresponding AP exam. Calculators are available to students for in -class use when appropriate based on instruction. courses.courseName: Elements of Data Science KAP A
courses.subject: Math
courses.enrollmentNotes: There is no academic equivalent for this course.
courses.courseDescription: In this course, students will utilize statistical concepts with the aid of technology to develop computational thinking and exploratory data analysis skills that will allow them to analyze large -scale datasets. Calculators are available to students for in-class use when appropriate based on instruction. Katy ISD high school campuses currently use the TI-Nspire CX II calculator or Desmos, a free online graphing calculator. Students may access Desmos on any device with the internet. If purchasing their own calculator, students should select one that offers the capabilities and features of the TI -Nspire CX II. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.enrollmentNotes: Students who take Precalculus are not eligible to take AP Precalculus as the TEKS in Precalculus are duplicated in AP Precalculus.

courses.subject: Social Studies
courses.enrollmentNotes: This course satisfies the World History high school graduation requirement.
courses.courseDescription: This course offers students an overview of the history of humankind. The major emphasis is on the study of significant people, events and issues from the earliest time to the present based on traditional points of reference. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Social Studies
courses.enrollmentNotes: This course satisfies the World History high s chool graduation requirement.
courses.courseDescription: In this course, students investigate significant events, individuals, developments, and processes in world history from approximately 8000 BC to the present. Students will apply historical thinking skills and use historical inquiry throughout the course. Students enrolled in an Advanced Placement course are expected to take the corresponding AP exam. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Social Studies
courses.enrollmentNotes: This course satisfies the US History high school graduation requirement.
courses.courseDescription: This course focuses on developing students‚Äô abilities to think conceptually about U.S. history from approximately 1491 to the present and apply historical thinking skills. Students will develop and use the same skills and methods employed by historians, including analyzing primary and secondary sources, developing historical arguments, and making historical connections. Students enrolled in an Advanced Placement course are expected to take the corresponding AP exam. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Social Studies
courses.enrollmentNotes: HCC admissions requirements; TSI requirement. This course satisfies the US History high school graduation requirement. Students may not duplicate credit by taking AP, Academic, and Dual Credit US History courses**.**
courses.courseDescription: The first semester traces the American nation from English colonization to the close of the Civil War through Reconstruction. The second semester covers the American nation from the end of the Reconstruction Era to the present. Students earn three college credit hours upon successful completion of each semester. Completing the full year course satisfies the high school US History graduation credit requirement. College Credit is provided by Houston Community College (HCC). NOTE: Due to the end-of-course (EOC) exam requirement, Dual Credit US History must be taken on a Katy ISD campus and cannot be taken during summer school. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Social Studies

courses.subject: Social Studies
courses.enrollmentNotes: This course satisfies the high school graduation credit for US Government.
courses.courseDescription: This one semester course provides an understanding of national, state and local governments. The course highlights the origins and development of the American government, the nature of American politics and the functions of the various branches. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Social Studies
courses.enrollmentNotes: This course does not satisfy the US Government high school graduation requirement.
courses.courseDescription: This course introduces students to fundamental concepts used by political scientists to study the processes and outcomes of politics in a variety of country settings. It examines the political institutions and processes of six different countries - China, Iran, Mexico, Nigeria, Russia, and the United Kingdom - and compares the ways these countries address problems. Students analyze data and readings to draw conclusions about political systems. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Social Studies
courses.enrollmentNotes: This course satisfies the high school graduation credit for Economics.
courses.courseDescription: This one-semester course focuses on the processes by which people earn a living and the relationships between production, distribution and consumption of wealth and income. The basic principles of economics, the American free enterprise system, personal financial literacy, and the economic-government relationship are emphasized. NOTE: Students may successfully complete Personal Financial Literacy and Economics OR this course to satisfy the half-credit economics requirement for high school graduation. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Social Studies
courses.enrollmentNotes: This course satisfies the Economics high school graduation requirement.
courses.courseDescription: This one-semester course covers the principles of economics that apply to an economic system as a whole with particular emphasis on the study of national income and price determination. Students also develop familiarity with economic performance measures, economic growth, and international economics. Students enrolled in an Advanced Placement course are expected to take the corresponding AP exam. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Social Studies
courses.enrollmentNotes: For the Classes of 2026‚Äì2028, this course is an elective and does not fulfill the Economics graduation requirement. Students in these cohorts may not earn credit for both the Personal Financial Literacy course and Economics and the Personal Financial Literacy elective course. Beginning with the Class of 2029 and all subsequent cohorts, completion of a Personal Financial Literacy course is required to meet graduation requirements. Students in the Class of 2029 and beyond may not enroll in Personal Financial Literacy and Economics or the semester-long Economics course.
courses.courseDescription: This one-semester elective course is designed to help students develop the knowledge and skills to make sound, informed financial decisions that will allow them to become financially responsible. The course will teach students to apply critical-thinking and problem- solving skills to analyze decisions involving earning and spending, saving and investing, credit and borrowing, insuring and protecting, and college and post-secondary education and training. NOTE: This course is not recognized by NCAA as an approved core course. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Social Studies
courses.enrollmentNotes: For the Classes of 2026‚Äì2028, this course fulfills the Economics graduation requirement. Credit may be earned for either Personal Financial Literacy and Economics (this course) or Economics but not both. Beginning with the Class of 2029 and all subsequent cohorts' completion of a Personal Financial Literacy course is required for graduation. Students in the Class of 2029 and beyond may not enroll in Personal Financial Literacy and Economics or the semester-long Economics course.
courses.courseDescription: The Personal Financial Literacy and Economics Course emphasizes the economic way of thinking, which serves as a framework for the personal financial decision-making opportunities introduced in the course. Students will demonstrate the ability to anticipate and address financial challenges as these challenges occur over their lifetime. NOTE: Students may successfully complete Economics OR this course to satisfy the half-credit economics requirement for high school graduation. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.courseDescription: This one-semester course includes an introduction to social behavior and the organization of human society. Students engage in a comprehensive study of the family, social institutions, and cultural variations. Sociology prepares students for college level studies and provides them with a better understanding of society. This course contains mature content. NOTE: This course involves sensitive issues that are presented appropriately for the age level. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Social Studies
courses.enrollmentNotes: This course satisfies the Economics high school graduation requirement.
courses.courseDescription: This one-semester course gives students a thorough understanding of the principles of economics that apply to functions of individual decision makers, both consumers and producers, within the economic system, with an emphasis on the nature and functions of product markets. This course also includes the study of factor markets and the role of government in promoting greater efficiency and equity in the economy. Students enrolled in an Advanced Placement course are expected to take the corresponding AP exam. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Social Studies
courses.enrollmentNotes: SS Research Methods KAP is a prerequisite for AP Psychology and must be taken in the fall. AP Psychology will be taken in the spring. Students may not receive credit for both Dual Credit Psychology and AP Psychology.
courses.courseDescription: AP Psychology builds on students‚Äô knowledge of the systematic, scientific study of behavior and mental processes of humans and other animals. Students are exposed to psychological facts, principles and phenomena associated with each of the major subfields within psychology and study ethics and methods used by psychologists in their science and practice. This course involves mature content. Students enrolled in an Advanced Placement course are expected to take the corresponding AP exam. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.courseName: SS Research Methods KAP A&B - VirSup(Fall)
courses.subject: Social Studies
courses.enrollmentNotes: Fall registration for the AP Psychology exam is recommended for students taking Social Studies Research Methods KAP in the fall semester. There is a late fee charged to students who register for the AP Psychology Exam in the spring semester. Social Studies Research Methods is a prerequisite course for AP Psychology. Students who have already received credit for AP Psychology or Dual Credit Psychology are not eligible to take this course.
courses.courseDescription: Social Studies Research Methods is a prerequisite course for AP Psychology. This course introduces students to the systematic, scientific study of the behavior and mental processes of humans and other animals. This course prepares students for success in AP Psychology and the requisite AP exam. Topics covered in this course involve mature, college -level content and engage students in research methods and case studies. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Social Studies
courses.enrollmentNotes: Students may not duplicate credit by taking African American Studies and AP African American Studies. NOTE: This course involves sensitive issues that are presented appropriately for the age level.
courses.courseDescription: This conceptually driven course introduces students to the exploration of the rich and diverse history and culture of African Americans and provides students with an opportunity to engage with the social, economic, and political activities of African Americans in a way that allows them to make deep connections across the content. The historical content of this course is taught with relevance to contemporary and current issues in order to ensure a deeper understanding for students. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.courseDescription: In this course, students learn about the history and cultural contributions of Mexican Americans and explore these concepts from an interdisciplinary perspective. An examination of the impact Mexican Americans have on American society allows students to develop a more well-rounded perspective on citizenship and American identity . NOTE: This course involves sensitive issues that are presented appropriately for the age level. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Social Studies
courses.enrollmentNotes: Students may not duplicate credit by taking African American Studies and AP African American Studies.
courses.courseDescription: This interdisciplinary course examines the diversity of African American experiences through direct encounters with varied sources. Students explore key topics that extend from early African kingdoms to the ongoing challenges and achievements of the contem porary moment. Students will develop skills across multiple fields with an emphasis on developing historical, literary, visual, and data analysis skills. NOTE: This course involves sensitive issues that are presented appropriately for the age level. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: HCC admissions requirements; TSI requirement. This course is an FHSPE third or fourth science credit option. HCC Course Codes: BIOL 2301 (Fall) and BIOL 2302 (Spring)
courses.courseDescription: Anatomy and Physiology ‚Äì Dual Credit Biology 2301/2301 is the study of human body systems for students who are interested in a career in health occupations. Through scientific inquiry, students will explore anatomical structures and physiological systems and the interactions between them. Campuses with embedded Katy ISD teachers will provide the required lab component for students to earn an advanced science credit towards high school graduation. For campuses without an embedded Katy ISD teacher, students have the option to take the lab course at the HCC Katy campus to earn an advanced science credit towards high school graduation. Otherwise, students will receive elective credit for successful course completion. College Credit is provided by Houston Community College (HCC). Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Science
courses.enrollmentNotes: It is highly recommended that Anatomy & Physiology AND Law Enforcement I be taken prior to this course. This supplemental course can count as one of the courses required to complete the program of study.
courses.courseDescription: This course uses a structured and scientific approach to the investigation of crimes. Students learn terminology and investigative procedures related to crime scene, questioning, interviewing, criminal behavior characteristics, truth detection and scientific procedures used to solve crimes. Students collect and analyze evidence through case studies and simulated crime scenes. Students will learn the history, legal aspects, and career options of forensic science. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.enrollmentNotes: It is highly recommended that Anatomy & Physiology AND Law Enforcement I be taken prior to this course. This supplemental course can count as one of the courses required to complete the program of study.
courses.courseDescription: This course uses a structured and scientific approach to the investigation of crimes. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Health
courses.enrollmentNotes: n/a
courses.courseDescription: This course is designed to empower students to make healthy choices for their physical, mental, and social well-being. Key topics include nutrition and fitness, stress management, personal safety, disease prevention, substance use awareness, and building positive relationships. Students will also practice decision-making and goal-setting skills that support lifelong health. By the end of the course, students will be better prepared to care for themselves and make responsible choices for a healthy future. NOTE: Parental consent must be provided for students to participate in lessons on human sexuality, child abuse, sex trafficking, dating violence, and family violence. Katy ISD follows an abstinence-only approach in its Health curriculum. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.courseDescription: Using current societal issues, students learn critical thinking and research skills as they develop both affirmative and negative arguments of policy and value issues using Lincoln -Douglas and Cross Examination debate formats to develop argumentation and speaking skills. courses.enrollmentNotes: Prerequisite: Journalism and /or instructor approval

courses.courseName: College Readiness and Study Skills (SAT/ACT Prep) - VirSup(Fall)
courses.subject: English Language Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: This virtual asynchronous course must be completed during the school year. There is a fee assigned and will be paid through Pay N' Go. Katy ISD Legacy Virtual School: https://lvhs.katyisd.org/
courses.courseDescription: This course is designed to develop critical thinking skills and provide an opportunity for students to master test- taking strategies for assessments such as the ACT or SAT. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: English Language Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: This course may be required for students who do not meet college readiness standards. This course satisfies the required FHSPE fourth English credit if the student has earned credit for English 1, English 2, and English 3 and graduates the same school year that College Prep English is successfully completed.
courses.courseDescription: College Prep English is designed for 12th grade students whose coursework, EOC scores, or college entrance exams (PSAT, ACT, SAT, TSIA, etc.) indicate that the student would benefit from further preparation for college -level coursework in English. This cou rse prepares students for success in entry -level college courses and/or success on the Texas Success Initiative Assessment (TSIA). This is a rigorous course that will include student learning outcomes and objectives th at include the principles of grammar, usage, and mechanics and utilizes the writing process to teach students to write formal essays and to address a variety of topics with multiple approaches. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Math
courses.enrollmentNotes: This course may be required for students who do not meet college readiness standards. This course satisfies the required FHSPE fourth Math credit if the student has earned credit for Algebra 1, Geometry, and a third math credit.
courses.courseDescription: College Prep Math is designed for 12th grade students whose coursework, EOC scores, or college entrance exams (PSAT, ACT, SAT, TSIA, etc.) indicate that the student would benefit from further preparation for college -level coursework in mathematics. This course prepares students for success in entry -level college courses and/or success on the Texas Success Initiative Assessment (TSIA). This is a rigorous course that will include student learning outcomes and objectives in the following areas: Elementary Algebra and Functions, Intermediate Algebra and Functions, Geometry and Measurement; and Data Analysis, Statistics, and Probability. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.courseDescription: This foundation course for computer programming emphasizes programming methodology and problem solving using packaged software and graphics. Students learn to code animation and games in various computer languages. This course is offered at the home campus.

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: Prerequisite: Algebra I
courses.courseDescription: Students are introduced to the foundations of computer science with a focus on how computing powers the world. This course is offered at the home campus.

courses.courseDescription: This course extends the understanding of what was learned in AP Computer Science A of programming through study of various contemporary programming techniques. This course is offered at the home campus.

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: Pre-requisites: Computer Science I OR AP Computer Science Principles
courses.courseDescription: Computer Science II expands on the foundation created in Computer Science I and introduces students to more advanced programming concepts. This course will introduce students to object-oriented programming where they will use Java to analyze, write, and test code. Students will explore concepts such as variables, looping, conditionals, and the fundamental building blocks of data structures. At the end of the course each student‚Äôs knowledge and skills will be challenged through an industry recognized certification in Java. This course is offered at the home campus.

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: n/a
courses.courseDescription: Introduction to Computer Science is a year-long course that does not require background knowledge in computer science. Students will learn about the computing tools that are used every day, while developing their ability to creatively solve real-world problems. Through interactive activities and projects students will learn computational thinking, problem-solving, and programming concepts. This course is offered on the home campus.

courses.courseName: Naval Science I PE Substitution A
courses.subject: Physical Education
courses.enrollmentNotes: Bus transportation will be provided by Katy ISD from the student's home campus to MCHS during 6th period. A late bus will also run back to the student's home campus at 4:30pm each day. The NJROTC program is ONLY offered at Mayde Creek High School.
courses.courseDescription: Naval Science I introduces students to the NJROTC program and includes Introduction to Leadership, Naval Ships, Mission and Organization, The Nation, Navy and the People in American Democracy, Maritime Geography, Sea Power and Challenge, Naval History through 1815, Introduction to Navigation and Time, Basic Seamanship, Health Education, First Aid and Drugs, and Alcohol and Tobacco Abuse Prevention. NOTE: This course satisfies a student's PE credit. This course is offered at Mayde Creek High School only.

courses.subject: Physical Education
courses.enrollmentNotes: Students in the graduating class of 2026 or 2027 are eligible for enrollment in this course. See https://www.katyisd.org/Page/4433 to download the program information packet and application.
courses.courseDescription: Off-Campus PE accommodates students who participate in specialized physical activities accelerated beyond those normally scheduled in the school district. All sports/activities require individual, one-to-one, directly supervised instruction. No team sports, including team sports private lessons, will be approved (i.e. basketball, hockey, lacrosse, soccer, baseball, softball, volleyball, etc.).

courses.courseDescription: Off-Campus PE accommodates students who participate in specialized physical activities accelerated beyond those normally scheduled in the school district. All sports/activities require individual, one -to- one, directly supervised instruction. No team sports , including team sports private lessons, will be approved (i.e. basketball, hockey, lacrosse, soccer, baseball, softball, volleyball, etc.). Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Language other than English
courses.enrollmentNotes: HCC admission requirements and TSI requirement
courses.courseDescription: Dual Credit Spanish Language further develops the students‚Äô ability to communicate effectively in Spanish. The development of communicative proficiency and use of the language in real -world situations is emphasized. In addition to the textbook, students use authentic materials in order to complete meaningful, real- world tasks and activities. Students earn three college credit hours per semester upon successful completion of each course. College Credit is provided by Houston Community College (HCC). Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.courseDescription: AP Latin students‚Äô reading and comprehension skills are enhanced, focusing on works by Horace, Catullus and Vergil. Students enrolled in an Advanced Placement course are expected to take the corresponding AP exam. Can be taken as an Elective.

courses.subject: Fine Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: NOTE: Students who participate in both band and athletics choose the full year Band/ Fine Arts options of 7011 or 7021. Course fee required (excludes instrument fees). See course fee list (click overview on left menu > student resources > student course fees)
courses.courseDescription: These performance-based courses stress the ability to play a variety of music, develop performance and marching skills, as well as leadership, organizational abilities, and cultural awareness, with greater musical proficiency, knowledge, and performance expectations each succeeding year. Band requires an extracurricular component including after school hours and weekend activities. Prerequisite: Previous instrumental experience strongly recommended. The fall semesters of Marching Band I and II satisfy the required PE credit for band students who do not participate in athletics. Can be taken as Elective

courses.enrollmentNotes: NOTE: A production fee may be assessed with campus administrative approval. Theatre satisfies the state communication skills component for graduation.
courses.courseDescription: Theatre emphasizes the development of performance skills, acting techniques, interpretation of dramatic literature and the historical evolution of performance styles. Principles of production are studied and applied through performance. Theatre requires extracurricular components, including after school and weekend activities. Advanced Theatre courses study the art form‚Äôs cultural contributions of the theatre, plays and performances while continuing to develop production styles and techniques through advanced acting, directing and production applications. Students develop and perform college- level audition material. Can be taken as Elective

courses.subject: Fine Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: n/a
courses.courseDescription: These courses combine study of various theories of design and stagecraft techniques with actual construction and operation of varied components of technical theatre. Students study staging, design, scenery, properties, lighting, costuming, makeup, and sound. Enrollment is limited due to safety requirements. Theatre Department production participation, including extracurricular components, after school and weekend activities, is required. Advanced courses emphasize design of scenic, properties, lighting, sound, costume, makeup and publicity as well as stage management and production and theatrical business management. These courses afford the opportunity to design projects and materials for professional portfolios for entrance into a university theatre program or theatrical career. Can be taken as Elective

courses.subject: Fine Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: HCC admissions requirements; TSI requirement. Course fee required. See course fee list (click overview on left menu > student resources > student course fees)
courses.courseDescription: A chronological analysis of the historical and cultural contexts of the visual arts from prehistoric times to the 14th century. This course is a global investigation of the styles and methods of artistic production covering Prehistoric through Gothic periods. Media studied include drawing, painting, sculpture, architecture, printmaking, textiles, ceramics, and metal arts. Using this framework, universal themes are studied within their historical, political, economic, theological, sociological, and ethnic contexts. This course satisfies the fine arts or component area option of the HCC core. Students will earn three hours of college credit after successfully completing course. Can be taken as Elective

courses.subject: Fine Arts
courses.enrollmentNotes: Art appreciation is a stand-alone course to earn the required fine arts credit for graduation. Art appreciation does not satisfy the prerequisite for all Art II, Art III, and Art IV Ceramics, Drawing, Painting and Sculpture courses.
courses.courseDescription: Art Appreciation allows students to develop a greater sensitivity to the visual world, its formal order and overall unity. Students develop an art vocabulary as well as skills to graphically express their own ideas and attitudes. Can be taken as Elective.

Students enrolled in an Advanced Placement course are expected to take the corresponding AP exam. Can be taken as Elective

courses.courseDescription: Students develop an understanding and knowledge of architecture, sculpture, painting, and other art forms within diverse historical and cultural contexts. Major forms of artistic expression from a variety of past and present cultures are studied. Students develop an understanding of the elements of art and fundamental art historical terminology as they learn to use intelligence and sensitivity in viewing works of art critically and analytically. Can be taken as Elective

courses.courseDescription: This course addresses a broad interpretation of two dimensional (2 D) design issues. Students use purposeful decision making to integrate the elements and principles of art as they create a portfolio to fulfill the requirements of the College Board Advanced Placement 2 Dimensional Design Portfolio. Students who choose Digital Art and Animation as their second art prerequisite should complete Art 1 prior to Digital Art and Animation. Can be taken as Elective

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: REQUIRED: MCTC Course Request Application - Selecting this course for planning purposes does not guarantee enrollment in the course.
courses.courseDescription: This course builds upon architectural design foundations and increases understanding of the overall process in a classroom and workplace environment. Major emphasis is placed on projects as they relate to the business world, including their processes, key definitions, budgets, schedules, and presentations. Projects are team-based involving cross-functional disciplines (engineering, project management) to derive cohesive solutions. Students may have the opportunity to gain field experience through field trips, guest speakers, and job shadowing. This course is offered at Miller Career and Technology Center.

courses.enrollmentNotes: Pre-requisites: Principles of Arts, Audio/Video Technology and Communications, Digital Arts and Animation
courses.courseDescription: Students are expected to develop an understanding of the commercial photography industry with a focus on creating quality photographs.

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: Pre-requisites: Principles of Arts, Audio/Video Technology and Communications, Digital Arts and Animation
courses.courseDescription: Students are expected to develop an understanding of the commercial photography industry with a focus on creating quality photographs.

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: Pre-requisites: Principles of Arts, Audio/Video Technology and Communications, Digital Arts and Animation, Commercial Photography I
courses.courseDescription: Careers in photography span all aspects of industry from setting up a shot to delivering products in a competitive market. Students develop advanced technical knowledge and skills needed for success in the Arts, Audio/Video Technology, and Communications pathway. Students will focus on developing an advanced technical understanding of the photography industry with emphasis on production, promotion, and presentation of professional quality photographs.

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: Pre-requisites: Principles of Arts, Audio/Video Technology and Communications, Digital Arts and Animation, Commercial Photography I
courses.courseDescription: Careers in photography span all aspects of industry from setting up a shot to delivering products in a competitive market. Students develop advanced technical knowledge and skills needed for success in the Arts, Audio/Video Technology, and Communications pathway. Students will focus on developing an advanced technical understanding of the photography industry with emphasis on production, promotion, and presentation of professional quality photographs.

courses.courseName: Prin of Arch - Underground Utly Detect Svcs
courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: n/a
courses.courseDescription: Principles of Architecture for Underground Utility Detection Services introduces students to the fundamentals of blueprint reading, project management, and safe work practices in the utility detection industry. Through hands-on activities and real-world applications, students will follow the full project management cycle from planning to execution. Emphasis is placed on applying industry best practices and safety techniques while building practical skills for careers in underground utility detection.

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: REQUIRED: MCTC Course Request Application - Selecting this course for planning purposes does not guarantee enrollment in the course.
courses.courseDescription: Principles of Construction provides an introduction for students entering the construction industry. Students will gain knowledge of construction safety, construction mathematics, and common hand and power tools. Principles of Construction provides skills needed for the building maintenance industry as a technician or supervisor. Students will acquire knowledge and skills in plumbing, electrical, and heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems. They will learn methods for repair and installation of drywall, roofing, and insulation systems. This course is offered at Miller Career and Technology Center.

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: REQUIRED: MCTC Course Request Application - Selecting this course for planning purposes does not guarantee enrollment in the course.

Principles of Construction provides skills needed for the building maintenance industry as a technician or supervisor. Students will acquire knowledge and skills in plumbing, electrical, and heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems. They will learn methods for repair and installation of drywall, roofing, and insulation systems. This course is offered at Miller Career and Technology Center.

The instruction also assists students seeking careers in the animation industry.

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: REQUIRED: MCTC Course Request Application - Selecting this course for planning purposes does not guarantee enrollment in the course.
courses.courseDescription: This course provides an introduction to the digital audio industry. Students explore audio careers in the areas of music production, live sound, film production, animation, game design, radio, and television. Using Digital Audio Workstations (DAWS) such as ProTools for recording and mixing, students will develop an understanding of the industry with a technical emphasis on production and critical listening skills. courses.courseDescription: Civil Engineering and Architecture is the study of the design and construction of residential and commercial building projects. The course includes an introduction to many of the varied factors involved in building design and construction including building components and systems, structural design, storm water management, site design, utilities and services, cost estimation, energy efficiency, and careers in the design and construction industry. The major focus of the CEA course is to expose students to the design and construction of residential and commercial building projects, design teams and teamwork, communication methods, engineering standards, and technical documents.

courses.enrollmentNotes: REQUIRED: MCTC Course Request Application - Selecting this course for planning purposes does not guarantee enrollment in the course.
courses.courseDescription: This course provides practical application of previously learned knowledge and skills through classroom and clinical settings. Students have the opportunity to rotate through various departments of area hospitals and community health centers while observing professional healthcare providers. Students are required to follow all immunization guidelines of the affiliated rotation sites. Note: Teachers collect fee for BLS card $8.00/year. Students must meet several requirements before school begins to maintain eligibility for this course. These requirements include, but are not limited to clear background check, negative drug screen, specific vaccinations and immunization records, health insurance, and proof of legal immigration status. Details will be provided to students accepted into the program at a mandatory orientation in the spring. Concurrent enrollment in a core course at MCTC. This course is offered at Miller Career and Technology Center.

Successful completion of Pharmacy I is required to progress to Pharmacy II.

Students must provide their own transportation to internship site.

Requirement: Student must have a social security number to register as a Technician in training and provide a specific clean drug test.

Prerequisites: Biology and Chemistry and Principles of Health Science+, Medical Terminology*+ & Health Science Theory+

*Students in the Class of 2026 are waived from the Medical Terminology prerequisite requirement.

+Students in the Class of 2027 and beyond who have only taken two of the three prerequisites may be considered on a deferred basis. Students who have all prerequisites will be considered first.

Note: All students must have completed Chemistry to be eligible for Pharmacy I.

Students must obtain a valid Driver’s License and obtain a Miller parking permit by the 3rd day of school to remain eligible.

Requirement: Student must have a social security number to register as a Technician in training and provide a specific clean drug test.

This course provides practical application of previously learned knowledge and skills in a pharmacy setting. Students learn how to ensure the health and safety of their patients, prepare prescription and refill requests, pack and label prescribed medications, process insurance claims, track inventory, and perform a wide range of duties for retail and hospital-based pharmacies. A non-paid internship at an approved pharmacy is required. This course is offered at Miller Career and Technology Center.

Students demonstrating required skills/competencies are eligible to take the Certified Veterinary Assisting (CVA) exam offered through the Texas Veterinary Medical Association (TVMA) in late May. Students who successfully pass the CVA exam receive a Practicum Pending Experience I CVA (PPE) certificate and will be eligible to obtain CVA certification after properly documenting an additional 300 hours of clinical experience.

courses.courseName: Pract in Const-Underground Utly Detect Svcs A
courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: n/a
courses.courseDescription: Practicum in Construction for Underground Utility Detection Services provides students with hands-on experience in locating underground utilities and applying industry-best practices. Students will spend two hours on a job site each day during the spring semester, gaining real-world experience in blueprint reading, electromagnetic locating theory, equipment use, and job site safety. Successful completion prepares students for entry into the utility locating industry and includes earning the OSHA 10-hour general industry card.

courses.courseDescription: This research-based course is for students to use the creative process of problem solving by identifying real-world needs and then devising solutions. courses.prerequisite: 8664VA or 8685VA or 8644VIRA or 2019A or 2000VIRA or 2006A or 0271A
courses.enrollmentNotes: MCTC Course Request Application - Selecting this course for planning purposes does not guarantee enrollment in the course. Successful completion of Cybersecurity I is required to progress to Cybersecurity II.
courses.courseDescription: This course provides an understanding of cybersecurity concepts, system vulnerabilities, common cyber-attack mechanisms and tools, intrusion detection systems, and methods to mitigate cybersecurity risks. Simulated and hands-on labs provide experience in various areas including firewall, router, and switch security, cryptography, encryption, VPNs, virtualization, steganography, hashing, security design principles, and social engineering. This course is offered at Miller Career and Technology Center.

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: Pre-requisite: AP Computer Science A OR Computer Science II KAP OR Computer Science II - Dual Credit
courses.courseDescription: Unity Game Development will build on the programming foundation developed in AP Computer Science A / Computer Science II. Students will build the skills necessary to design and develop 2D and 3D games. A few of the technical concepts that this course will cover are object-oriented programming, pathing algorithms, artificial intelligence, sound/image/model management, sprite creation, collision detection, and data storage. Students will collaborate with one another, their instructor, and various electronic communities to create multiple game projects in the latest Unity game engine. This course is offered at the home campus.

courses.courseName: AWS Advanced Cloud Computing KAP A
courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: Pre-requisite: AP Computer Science A OR Computer Science II KAP OR Computer Science II - Dual Credit
courses.courseDescription: The AWS Advanced Cloud Computing course is an exploration of cloud computing. Upon completion of the course, students are prepared to sit for the cloud computing professional certification. In this course, students explore AWS cloud computing services, applications, and use cases. Students dive deeply into cloud computing best practices and learn how cloud computing helps users develop a global infrastructure to support use case at scale while also developing and inventing innovative technologies. This course is offered at the home campus.

courses.enrollmentNotes: Pre-requisites: Principles of Business, Marketing, and Finance, Business Information Management I, Entrepreneurship I
courses.courseDescription: This course prepares students with the knowledge and skills needed to become a successful entrepreneur within an innovative marketplace. The goal and outcome of the course is for students to have their business launched by the end of the course or have the tools necessary to launch and operate their business. Students are encouraged to work in close cooperation with local industry leaders, community members, and educators to develop ideas and objectives, complete a business model canvas, pitch to potential investors, register with governmental agencies, develop their brand identity, and participate in local chamber of commerce meetings and events.

courses.enrollmentNotes: This course is offered at ALL High School Campuses.
courses.courseDescription: The College Board Career Kickstart Cybersecurity 1: Networking Fundamentals course introduces students to the foundations of computer networking, which is critical to understanding cybersecurity concepts at a deeper level. Using the OSI model as a blueprint for the course, students learn about various network devices like switches, routers, and firewalls, as well as protocols that power digital communication. This course is built to engage and support students with all levels of experience in computing. This course is aligned with and is a prerequisite for the Career Kickstart Cybersecurity 2: Cybersecurity Fundamentals course.

courses.enrollmentNotes: REQUIRED: MCTC Course Request Application - Selecting this course for planning purposes does not guarantee enrollment into the course.
courses.courseDescription: Automotive Technology I provides an introduction to the automotive industry and focuses on safety and environmental rules and regulations, tool identification, proper tool use, and employability skills. courses.courseDescription: This course provides an introduction to the cosmetology industry. Students develop knowledge and skills regarding various cosmetology design elements, such as form, lines, texture, structure, and illusion or depth as they relate to the art of cosmetology. Instruction includes sterilization and sanitation procedures, hair care, nail care, and skin care and meets the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation (TDLR) requirements for licensure upon passing the state examination. Analysis of career opportunities, license requirements, knowledge and skills expectations, and development of workplace skills are included. This course is offered at Miller Career and Technology Center.

courses.courseDescription: Naval Science IV provides instruction on theoretical and applied aspects of leadership, training, and evaluation of performance. Students learn motivational techniques, develop goals and activities for a work group, and proper ways to set a leadership example. courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: MCTC Course Request Application - Selecting this course for planning purposes does not guarantee enrollment in the course. Successful completion of Law Enforcement I is required to progress to Law Enforcement II. This course is offered at Miller Career and Technology Center.
courses.courseDescription: This course provides an introduction to the law enforcement industry. Students investigate the history and philosophy of criminal justice in Law Enforcement I. They experience real-world scenarios through a judgement and use of force simulator, analyze crime scenes, and practice traffic stops. In Law Enforcement II, students dive into the impact, crime trends, and theories related to the causes of crime. Students learn about the search and seizure process, as well as how both the interview and interrogation processes work. This course is offered at Miller Career and Technology Center.

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: REQUIRED: MCTC Course Request Application - Selecting this course for planning purposes does not guarantee enrollment in the course.
courses.courseDescription: This course provides an introduction to the legal studies industry. In Court Systems and Practices, students learn basics about the criminal justice system, structure of the American court system, prosecution, right to counsel, types and rules of evidence, and sentencing. Students participate in mock trials. In Advanced Legal Systems, students dive deeper into the practical application of the law, as well as civil and criminal procedures. Students gain an understanding of the attorney-client relationship and the importance of confidentiality, discovery, pretrial motions, jury selection, opening statements, direct and cross examinations, and closing arguments. Students will also learn how to evaluate a set of facts and mold it into a coherent trial strategy, learning trial practice from the ground floor. This course is offered at Miller Career and Technology Center.

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: REQUIRED: MCTC Course Request Application - Selecting this course for planning purposes does not guarantee enrollment in the course. Successful completion of Criminal Investigations is required to progress to Correctional Services.
courses.courseDescription: This course provides a more in-depth application of previously learned knowledge and skills. In Criminal Investigations, students learn terminology and procedures related to investigating crime scenes. They study evidence collection, fingerprinting, and courtroom presentation through case studies and simulated crime scenes. Students gain experience collecting and analyzing bodily fluids, hairs, fibers, shoe and tire impressions, bite marks, blood spatter, firearms and ammunition, and other types of evidence. In Correctional Services, students learn the roles and responsibilities of a county/municipal correctional officer. They discuss relevant rules, regulations, and laws of municipal, county, state, or federal facilities as well as defensive tactics, restraint techniques, and first aid procedures used in these settings. This course is offered at Miller Career and Technology Center.

courses.subject: CTE
courses.enrollmentNotes: HCC admission requirements; TSI requirement
courses.courseDescription: HCC Dual Credit tuition Instructional Practices in Education and Training provides juniors and seniors with the opportunity to explore the exciting career of teaching through classroom instruction and field experience in a school setting. Students observe and experience various aspects of teaching as they rotate through local Katy ISD schools and facilities. Field experiences provide students with experience in child development and principles of effective teaching practices. Course content includes leadership concepts and skills, employability skills, information on careers in education, and child growth and development. Instructional Practices in Education and Training covers topics related to children in Pre-Kindergarten through 8th grade.
